awd_titl_txt: Combined Modeling and Experimental Study of the Mechanisms of Growth Patterns in Stem Cell Homeostasis in Plants
awd_abstract_narration:
This project aims to understand how mechanical connections among cells and chemical signals between them collaborate to control the growth, sell-organization and differentiation of stem cells during plant growth.  Mathematical and computer models will allow researchers to perform virtual experiments that are currently impossible in the lab.  Coupled with live imaging experiments and new image analysis methods, these experiments will yield insights into biological mechanisms governing organ formation in plants and animals and development of cancer in epithelial cell layers of the colon. UC Riverside is a Hispanic-serving institution with very diverse student population and with many students being first in their families to attend college. The team will be actively working with undergraduate and graduate students from underrepresented groups as well as with high school students on the interdisciplinary projects related to proposed research program. Outreach activities will be coordinated with the newly established UC Riverside Interdisciplinary Center for Quantitative Modeling in Biology (ICQMB). Through ICQMB, regular meetings and workshops will be organized on topics at the interphase of biology and mathematical modeling, enriching other groups at UCR as well as other universities and colleges in Southern California.

The shoot apical meristems (SAMs) in plants harbor a set of stem cells that differentiate into cells for the development of all above-ground organs such as leaves, stem and branches that constitute the entire biomass required for sustaining life on earth. Like in animal systems, plant stem cell maintenance in SAMs involves conserved molecular mechanism of repression of differentiation in the context of a multilayered tissue.The main goal of this interdisciplinary research program is to combine development and calibration of a multiscale mathematical and computational modeling platform with specifically designed transient gene manipulations and live imaging methods for the spatio-temporal study of cell growth and division patterns that regulate stem cell maintenance and differentiation of stem cell progeny in SAMs. To date, the most advanced modeling efforts of cell division behavior in SAMs are restricted to the surface cell layers which also do not account for cell signaling in coordinating growth behaviors in this multi-layered structure. Modeling environment to be developed by the team will combine descriptions of molecular and mechanical signaling at several scales in all layers of the SAM to determine biological mechanisms resulting in correct shape and form of the SAM. In particular. multiscale model simulations will be used for testing hypothesis that WUSCHEL and cytokinin may function together and/or independently to influence cell wall growth, cell division rates and position of plane of cell division to organize the SAM growth.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
The stem cells are critical for development, repair and regeneration of tissues and organs in both animals and plants. A spatio-temporal regulation of gene expression and growth patterns are critical for the maintenance and differentiation of stem cells in multilayer stem cell niches.  The stem cells located at the growing apex called the shoot apical meristem (SAM) in plants contribute to the development of all above-ground organs that constitute nearly 80% of the biomass on earth. Deciphering the design principles of stem cell maintenance in stem cell niches is important in any efforts to optimize the biomass production and understand totipotency which is a hallmark of plant cells. We have developed several multiscale experimental-computational modeling frameworks that coupled the dynamical representation of a chemical network of cell-cell signaling with submodels of mechanical properties of cell growth and division to study stem cell maintenance in SAM.

A novel, subcellular element computational model of growth of stem cells within the multilayered SAM of Arabidopsis thaliana was developed and calibrated using experimental data. Novel features of the model include separate, detailed descriptions of cell wall extensibility and mechanical stiffness, deformation of the middle lamella, and increase in cytoplasmic pressure generating internal turgor pressure. The model was used to test novel hypothesized mechanisms of formation of the shape and structure of the growing, multilayered SAM based on WUS concentration controlling cell growth rates and layer-dependent anisotropic mechanical properties of subcellular components. Then, a pseudo-three-dimensional (P3D) multiscale model of a longitudinal section of the SAM was developed. It includes anisotropic expansion and division of cells out of the cross-section plane. Modeling results provided new insights into maintenance of the structure of the SAM epidermal cell monolayer under tension and quantified dependence of epidermal and subepidermal cell anisotropy on the amount of tension. 

Towards understanding the regulation of WUS protein gradient, we employed a combined experimental and computational modeling approach that integrated receptor kinase signaling mediated by the CLAVATA3 (CLV3) ligand. By applying a computational model that integrates WUS concentration-dependent regulation of CLV3 with the dual regulation of CLV3 signaling in regulating WUS protein gradient, it was showen that the dual control by the same signal forms a seamless connection between de novo WUS synthesis and sub-cellular partitioning in providing robustness to the WUS gradient. To better understand the WUS-binding properties to the multiple cis-elemets in the cis regulatory module (CRM) of the CLV3 promoter, we developed a stochastic computational model calibrated by experimental data to investigate the concentration-dependent transcriptional regulation. Our work showing a constellation of optimally spaced cis-elements of defined affinities determining activation and repression thresholds in regulating CLV3 transcription provides a previously unknown mechanism of cofactor-independent regulation of transcription factor binding in mediating gene expression specificity.

The PI and co-PIs organized several international and national conferences and workshops, as well as performed other outreach activities. In particular, PI Dr. Alber and Co-PI Dr. Chen were the Chair and Associate Chair Organizing Committee.  of the Annual Virtual Meeting of the Society of Mathematical Biology (SMB2021) which had a special emphasis on the impact of Mathematical Biology on Translational Science & Promotion of Diversity, Equity, and Inclusion (DEI). The SMB2021 was held in a virtual form during pandemic between June 13-17, 2021, 24 hours a day to maximize the participation of researchers across the world with the help of the meeting partner societies: Society for Mathematical Biology (SMB), European Society for Mathematical and Theoretical Biology (ESMTB) and Korean Society for Industrial and Applied Mathematics (KSIAM).  SMB2021 had a total of 2585 registered attendees from 47 countries. Co-PI Dr. Reddy?s group participated in the 2019 Plant Discovery Day on April 26, 2019, at UCR where many of the 150 local fifth-grade students from Highland Elementary had their first opportunity to learn about college and how higher education could fit into their futures. The group led the strawberry DNA extraction and mathematical/computational biology booths to get students (potential first generation college students) interested in the STEM field. 

Several graduate students, including students from underrepresented groups, supported by this grant, successfully defended their PhD theses. Mikahl Banwarth-Kuhn did her postdoc training at UC Merced after graduating from UCR and now is an assistant professor at California State University, East Bay. Samuel Britton works as a Radar Signal Processing Engineer at the Aerospace Corporation. Christian Michael is now a postdoctoral scholar at the University of Michigan. Kevin Rodriguez is now an assistant professor at The University of The South. Alex Plong, a graduate student who performed experiments, is a programmer working in industry.
